Personal protective equipment (PPE) is specialised clothing or equipment worn by healthcare workers for their protection and to help prevent the spread of infection between patients. It includes gloves, gowns, aprons, goggles or visors and facemasks. Wearing PPE does not guarantee total protection and must be used in combination with precautionary measures such as meticulous ‘doffing’ (protocolised removal of PPE to minimise the risk of self-contamination) and rigorous hand hygiene.
27 Fluid-resistant surgical facemasks are used to block large particles such as droplets or splashes that may contain micro-organisms such as viruses and bacteria from reaching the nose and mouth. They can also be equipped with a visor to protect the eyes.
28 These masks generally do not form a tight seal against the face and so are not recommended as protection from airborne infectious diseases (aerosols).
